title: Health Issues
body:
A claimant’s poor health has resulted in sporadic periods off work. They have always called their employer in advance to advise them of the situation.

It has been shown that the claimant did not have the ability to do the job requested. Last month the claimant thought they were acting in the best interest of the company when making a decision, but it turned out to be the wrong decision and lost the company important clients.

After numerous justifiable verbal and written warnings and days off with and without pay, the claimant was advised the next occurrence of lateness or absenteeism would result in dismissal. The next week, as a result of emergency hospitalization due to an infected gall bladder, the claimant was fired.

Even though some of the claimant’s previous actions could be considered misconduct, the event, which led to their dismissal, was a legitimate health issue and as such, misconduct was not the reason for his separation from employment.

title: Knowledge Check - Voluntary Leaving vs Dismissal
displayTitle: Knowledge Check - Voluntary Leaving vs Dismissal
body:
Edward was fired for stealing.

Solange quit because of poor working conditions.

Whose termination of employment would be considered Voluntary Leaving?
instruction: Choose one answer and then select Submit to complete this question.

_items.feedback:
Unfortunately, you have selected the INCORRECT answer.

The correct answer is Solange’s termination of employment. Solange took the initiative to leave their employment so it would be considered Voluntary Leaving. Edward was fired so it was the employer who took the initiative in ending the employment contract.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: The answer is: Solange’s termination of employment. Solange took the initiative to leave their employment so it would be considered Voluntary Leaving. Edward was fired so it was the employer who took the initiative in ending the employment contract.

_incorrect.final: The correct answer is: Solange’s termination of employment. Solange took the initiative to leave their employment so it would be considered Voluntary Leaving. Edward was fired so it was the employer who took the initiative in ending the employment contract.

title: Disqualification
body:
In rare cases, it may be difficult to distinguish if the claimant quit without just cause or was terminated due to misconduct. Either way, in these cases, a disqualification will be recommended to the Adjudicator (Service Canada Benefit Officer (SCBO)). Jurisprudence in the Federal Court case of Easson, A-1598-92, stated that either way, the disqualification will be upheld.

Select the link to learn more. The full text of the judge’s decision can be found in the Jurisprudence Library.

Dismissal is the issue that is examined when the employer took the initiative in severing the employee/employer relationship. When one is unable to distinguish between VL without just cause and dismissal amounting to misconduct, a disqualification is recommended either way.

title: What is the difference?
instruction: Select the arrow buttons (next/previous) to learn how to differentiate between Voluntary Leaving and dismissal. Open/read all five slides to complete this section and continue.

_items.title: Who took the initiative?
_items.body: The person who takes the initiative in the separation from employment is the key difference between Voluntary Leaving and Dismissal.

_items.title: Claimant
_items.body: In situations of Voluntary Leaving the initiative is taken by the claimant.

_items.title: Onus of Proof
_items.body: As you saw in the previous module on Voluntary Leaving (VL), the Commission has to first prove that VL took place, and then the onus of proving just cause rests with the claimant.

_items.title: Employer
_items.body: In situations of dismissal the initiative is taken by the employer.

_items.title: Dismissal for Misconduct
_items.body: In the case of a dismissal for misconduct, we have to prove that it was the employer who took the initiative in the separation from employment. This proof is usually satisfied by the Reason For Separation (RFS) on the application for benefits and the Record of Employment (ROE).

title: Scenario 1
body:
The claimant, a former manager in a marketing firm, was asked by their boss to reorganize one of their territories. They were told the change was needed due to a major stockholder wanting a relative to have responsibility in a particular territory. When the claimant disagreed with the change, they were told to go along with the request or look for work elsewhere.

The claimant refused to implement the change and was let go.

Did they leave voluntarily or were they dismissed?
instruction: Choose one answer and then select Submit to complete this question.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
The answer is: Employee was dismissed.

The employer initiated the separation. The issue is one of dismissal for misconduct. Although the claimant refused to implement the change which led to his dismissal, it was the employer who finally decided to dismiss his employee.

_incorrect.final:
The correct answer is: Employee was dismissed.

The employer initiated the separation. The issue is one of dismissal for misconduct. Although the claimant refused to implement the change which led to his dismissal, it was the employer who finally decided to dismiss his employee.

title: Scenario 2
body:
The claimant was an assembly line worker at an electronics plant. On several occasions, they expressed their dissatisfaction with the working conditions to their supervisor. One day they complained about being assigned a disproportionate share of dirty jobs, they were told, “if you don’t like it, quit.”

The supervisor then went into the office, got a termination slip and told the claimant to sign it. The claimant signed the termination slip, which stated “Released”.

Did they leave voluntarily or were they dismissed?
instruction: Choose one answer and then select Submit to complete this question.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
The answer is: Employee was dismissed. 

The employer initiated the separation from employment. The issue is one of Misconduct. The employer presented a situation in which the employee had no choice but to sign the termination slip. The fact the termination slip reads “Released” is further evidence the claimant did not take the initiative to become unemployed.

_incorrect.final:
The correct answer is: Employee was dismissed. 

The employer initiated the separation from employment. The issue is one of Misconduct. The employer presented a situation in which the employee had no choice but to sign the termination slip. The fact the termination slip reads “Released” is further evidence the claimant did not take the initiative to become unemployed.

title: Scenario 3
body:
The claimant worked as a word processor at a large law firm. After three months, they were still unable to operate the word processing equipment efficiently and effectively. The claimant told their supervisor that they were quitting because the job was too difficult. The supervisor said “Good, because we were about to let you go.”

Did the claimant leave voluntarily or were they dismissed?
instruction: Choose one answer and then select Submit to complete this question.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
The answer is: Employee left voluntarily.

The employee initiated the separation. The claimant handed in a verbal resignation before the employer was able to dismiss.

_incorrect.final:
The correct answer is: Employee left voluntarily.

The employee initiated the separation. The claimant handed in a verbal resignation before the employer was able to dismiss.

title: Summary – Voluntary Leaving vs Dismissal
body:
In this section, you have learned how to:

  • differentiate between Voluntary Leaving and Dismissal; and
  • determine if the claimant left their employment voluntarily or if they were dismissed for Misconduct.

In the case of Voluntary Leaving, it is the claimant who took the initiative to end their employment; whereas with a claim of Dismissal, it is the employer who took the initiative.

When it is difficult to determine if the claimant left without just cause or was terminated due to misconduct a disqualification will be recommended to the BISB Adjudicator.

title: What consitutes misconduct?
body:
In general, misconduct refers to ill-intentioned actions by an employee; actions that are incompatible with the reliable and suitable carrying-out of the duties for which the employee was hired.

It is not necessary that the misconduct occur during work or at the workplace or even while carrying-out duties for the employer. An offence committed at a place other than at work or outside of working hours could still amount to misconduct if it led to the dismissal.

In order to constitute misconduct, the actions or omissions must have been voluntary or wilful or of such a careless or negligent nature, that it appears to have been committed deliberately.

Misconduct involves the claimant's own behaviour or responsibilities for which they are personally accountable.

The following will not amount to misconduct unless it is shown to be a result of wilful actions or the result of unwillingness on the part of the claimant:

  • Incompetence;
  • Unsatisfactory performance;
  • Inaptitude to perform certain duties;
  • An error attributable to intense pressure at work or inexperience.

title: Who has the onus of proof?
displayTitle: Who has the onus of proof?
body:
It has been established by the courts that the onus of proof to establish misconduct rests with the Commission

If there is an indication on the ROE or the application for benefit that the claimant was dismissed, the fact-finding should start with the employer. This process of starting the fact-finding with the employer will then facilitate a rebuttal of those facts by the claimant. This will satisfy the requirement that the claimant be given the last say on the issue.

title: RFS changed on ROE due to grievance or wrongful dismissal
displayTitle: RFS changed on ROE due to grievance or wrongful dismissal
body: An original determination of misconduct based on sound fact-finding and positive replies to the four questions will not be altered by the fact that the reason for separation on an amended ROE was changed to laid off as the result of a grievance. We may also see this in a case of wrongful dismissal. Therefore, although misconduct was the original reason for dismissal it is no longer an issue based on the amended ROE.

title: Fact-finding - Question
body: Thinking about the various elements that have been presented about the fact-finding process, how would you explain this process as it applies to dismissal for Misconduct?
instruction: Enter your answer then select Submit complete this question. Note you are limited to 1500 characters.
modelAnswer:
Did you get it right?

It is up to the Commission to prove that the claimant was in fact terminated for Misconduct. In order to prove this, fact-finding should start with the employer so that the claimant has the last say on the issue and can rebut the facts provided by the employer.

Other factors to take into consideration are credibility and the benefit of the doubt based on documented details of the incidents and the employer’s actions. You cannot simply take the employer’s word that Misconduct occurred; there must be documentation to back it up.

If either the employer or the claimant refuse to provide information about the reason for separation, as per the EI Act we can demand that the two parties provide us with the required information. However, we usually only use this legislation to compel the claimant to provide us with the information. And, if the employer has provided the requested evidence but the claimant refuses to comply, a D-10 disqualification is recommended.

There are also situations in which Misconduct is no longer an issue that will be discovered during the fact-finding process, such as dismissal for health issues or the reason for separation (RFS) was changed on the record of employment (ROE).

title: Question 2
body: When the claimant admits to misconduct such as punching their boss at work a recommendation of D-10 misconduct can be made without further fact-finding.
instruction: Choose one answer and then select Submit to complete this question.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
The answer is: False.

Section 51 of the EI Act states that it is mandatory to fact find with the employer, therefore, the answer is false.

_incorrect.final:
The correct answer is: False.

Section 51 of the EI Act states that it is mandatory to fact find with the employer, therefore, the answer is false.

title: Question 3
body:
The claimant, a manager of a retail store, was fired when the employer discovered she was an alcoholic and had been attending Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) for the last 15 years. Further fact-finding revealed that the claimant has never had a drink since joining AA.

The claimant started her job with the retail store nine years ago. The claimant stated she advised her manager when she initially joined the company, which was verified with the existing personnel manager, however, the existing CEO has adopted a zero tolerance policy. Due to being an alcoholic, a D-10 - disqualification for misconduct is in order.
instruction: Choose one answer and then select Submit to complete this question.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
The answer is: False.

Being fired for being an alcoholic over 15 years ago, even before the claimant was hired is not the immediate cause of dismissal, nor is it improper conduct. There is no causal effect of an action that took place so many years before the employment started especially since the manager at hiring was aware of the claimant’s condition.

_incorrect.final:
The correct answer is: False.

Being fired for being an alcoholic over 15 years ago, even before the claimant was hired is not the immediate cause of dismissal, nor is it improper conduct. There is no causal effect of an action that took place so many years before the employment started especially since the manager at hiring was aware of the claimant’s condition.

title: Question 4
body: All claimants who are fired from their employment will be disqualified.
instruction: Choose one answer and then select Submit to complete this question.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
The answer is: False.

The individual circumstances of each case must be examined to determine if misconduct exists. Only when misconduct is proven to exist will a disqualification be applicable.

_incorrect.final:
The correct answer is: False.

The individual circumstances of each case must be examined to determine if misconduct exists. Only when misconduct is proven to exist will a disqualification be applicable.

title: Question 5
body:
The claimant was a childcare worker at the local nursery school. She worked from noon to 6pm, Monday to Friday. She had previously been disciplined for lateness and absenteeism. She was warned three times and given one, two and three-day suspensions. She was advised that any more lateness or absenteeism in the next six months would result in her dismissal for cause.

Yesterday she phoned into work at 11am and stated that she had just visited the doctor and was told to take two weeks off work due to "Pink Eye" which is highly contagious. Her manager stated she was fired due to absenteeism as she was previously warned. Both the claimant and employer agreed with these facts. No misconduct applies.
instruction: Choose one answer and then select Submit to complete this question.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
The answer is: True.
Since the last event that caused the claimants dismissal was not improper conduct, it is true. No misconduct applies.

_incorrect.final:
The correct answer is: True.
Since the last event that caused the claimants dismissal was not improper conduct, it is true. No misconduct applies.

title: Conclusion
body:
You have now completed the Benefit Entitlement – Misconduct module.

You should now be able to:

  • determine the difference between Voluntary Leaving and Misconduct;
  • explain misconduct for Integrity purposes;
  • apply the four questions to determine if the reason for dismissal can be deemed misconduct;
  • explain the fact-finding process as it applies to dismissal for misconduct; and
  • determine if a claim should or should not be allowed based on the four possible recommendations on what action should be taken as a result of an investigation.

You have seen that when trying to determine if misconduct is the reason for a separation from employment, you must find out who took the initiative, the employer or employee and the stated reason for that separation. It must be determined if the reason for this separation was voluntary leave or misconduct.

You have learned that, for our purposes, misconduct can be defined as “improper behaviour” or “improper conduct”. If misconduct has been stated as the reason for separation, the matter must be thoroughly investigated as the onus of proof is on the commission to verify the claims of the employer and treat the claimant fairly. You must ensure that all fact-finding has been thoroughly documented.

Ensure you have reviewed the facts prior to contacting an employer or a claimant and ensure you have questions, which will provide answers to the four questions for determining misconduct. You can be certain that, if you have received truthful information and an affirmative answer to all four of the questions, misconduct has occurred because of the claimant’s actions or inaction. Once the four questions have been answered, you may then make your recommendation and determine if the claim should be allowed or if a disentitlement or disqualification should be imposed.

title: Disqualification
body:
Similar to voluntary leaving, an indefinite disqualification is imposed for misconduct when all three questions are answered in the affirmative, and the claimant does not have enough insured hours to establish a claim subsequent to the disqualifying event.

The recommendation would be a disqualification (D-10 - Dismissal - Misconduct Proven).

The indefinite disqualification will be suspended for special benefits, i.e., sickness, maternity, parental or compassionate care.

A disqualification is not suspended for claimants participating in employment interventions such as those found in Sections 24 and 25 of the EI Act. 

 Select the link to learn more: Section 24 of the EI Act – Work Sharing and 25 of the EI Act – Training.

title: Excluded ROE
body: Like voluntary leaving, if the claimant has enough insured hours to establish a new claim subsequent to the disqualifying event, that ROE will be excluded from rate calculation and duration.

title: Disentitlement
body:
Similar to a leave of absence for voluntary leaving, if the claimant is suspended due to proven Misconduct, the indefinite disqualification (D-10 - Dismissal - Misconduct Proven) is changed to a definite disentitlement (D-42 - Suspension From Employment for Misconduct) for the period of the suspension.

Like voluntary leaving, if the proven Misconduct occurs within three weeks of a known termination of employment, the indefinite disqualification (D-10) is changed to a disentitlement (D44 - Loss of Employment in Anticipation of Lay-Off).

title: Claim Allowed
body: A claimant may be dismissed for frivolous reasons or without adequate proof. In such a case, the claim will be allowed. We need to remember that the Commission’s definition of Misconduct does not need to be the same as an employer’s definition.

title: Summary - Making a Recommendation
body:
You have now learned how to:

  • determine if a claim should or should not be allowed based on the four possible recommendations on what action should be taken as a result of an investigation

The four recommendations are:

  • Proven Misconduct = Indefinite Disqualification (D-10)
  • Proven Misconduct Impacts Rate and Duration Misconduct Suspension = Disentitlement (D-42)
  • Misconduct within Three Weeks of Employment Ending = D-44 Anticipated loss of employment
  • No Proof of Misconduct = Claim Allowed

title: How to Deal with This Type of Investigation
displayTitle: How to Deal with This Type of Investigation
instruction: Select the arrow buttons (next/previous) to learn what you need to do when faced with this situation. Open/read all five slides to complete this section and continue.

_items.title: Employee
_items.body: I have a file here where the employer is stating on the ROE that the claimant was fired for misconduct. Do I have to look into this any further?

_items.title: Trainer
_items.body: The fact that the employer has alleged that the claimant is guilty of misconduct is not sufficient for a Commission finding of misconduct.

_items.title: Evidence
_items.body: Misconduct cannot be presumed. It must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.

_items.title: Opinion vs Fact
_items.body: Opinions, or mere suppositions, are not satisfactory evidence; only established facts can be accepted.

_items.title: Four Questions
_items.body:
Misconduct is proven when the following four questions are answered in the affirmative:

  1. Was the alleged offence the immediate cause for dismissal?
  2. Does the information in this case suggest that the claimant did in fact commit the offence?
  3. Is the offence considered misconduct?
  4. Was the offence committed because of ill-intentioned voluntary or willful actions performed by the claimant?

title: Was the alleged offence the immediate cause for dismissal?
displayTitle: Was the alleged offence the immediate cause for dismissal?
body:
What is important here is that the offence committed was the immediate cause for the claimant’s dismissal and was not some action by the claimant sometime in the past, which the employer is now using as an excuse to release the claimant.

The time elapsed between the date of the alleged misconduct and the date on which the employment is terminated may indicate whether the alleged misconduct was the true reason for the dismissal.

Doubt as to the real reason for dismissal may arise when the employer took the time to find a replacement, or when the time that elapsed between the two events is abnormally long, unless it was necessary for a more detailed enquiry or investigation of the incident by the employer.

title: Knowledge Check - The First Question
body: In which of these situations was the alleged offence the immediate cause for dismissal?
instruction: Select all that apply then select Submit to complete this question and continue.

_items.text: David was fired in August, three months after they were reprimanded for being late every day for a week in May.
Darlène was fired a week after they showed up at work inebriated.
Casper was let go the day they were caught stealing money from a co-worker.
Elyana was being aggressive towards their co-workers off and on in the fall of 2022 and she was fired in April 2023.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
You selected the CORRECT answers.

The answers are:

  • Darlène was fired a week after she showed up at work intoxicated.
  • Casper was let go the day he was caught stealing money from a co-worker.

Darlène and Casper were fired almost immediately after the alleged incident so it is most likely that the alleged offence was the immediate cause for dismissal.

In the case of David and Elyana, the alleged offence took place many months before they were fired so it is most likely not the immediate cause for their dismissal.

_incorrect.final:
Unfortunately, you selected the INCORRECT answers.

The correct answers are:

  • Darlène was fired a week after she showed up at work intoxicated.
  • Casper was let go the day he was caught stealing money from a co-worker.

Darlène and Casper were fired almost immediately after the alleged incident so it is most likely that the alleged offence was the immediate cause for dismissal.

In the case of David and Elyana, the alleged offence took place many months before they were fired so it is most likely not the immediate cause for their dismissal.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Your answer is only PARTLY CORRECT.

The correct answers are:

  • Darlène was fired a week after she showed up at work intoxicated.
  • Casper was let go the day he was caught stealing money from a co-worker.

Darlène and Casper were fired almost immediately after the alleged incident so it is most likely that the alleged offence was the immediate cause for dismissal.

In the case of David and Elyana, the alleged offence took place many months before they were fired so it is most likely not the immediate cause for their dismissal.

title: Does the information in this case suggest that the claimant did in fact commit the offence?
displayTitle: Does the information in this case suggest that the claimant did in fact commit the offence?
body:
Misconduct is very specific in nature. It must be clearly established that it was the claimant who committed the offence.

It is important that the conclusion of dismissal for misconduct be drawn from the evidence on the file. An absolute certainty that the claimant committed the offence and lost employment by reason of the action or omission is not required.

What must be established is personal misconduct. Dismissal must be shown to have resulted from the claimant’s own behaviour or from an action for which the claimant is personally responsible.

title: Knowledge Check - The Second Question
body: Which of these situations would you consider to be personal misconduct?
instruction: Select all that apply then select Submit to complete this question and continue.

_items.text: Mandy intentionally broke their Manager’s chair in anger.
Christian was angry and sat in their Manager’s chair and it broke.
Everton arrived at work wearing their pyjamas because their Manager told them it was casual day.
Nancy wore their pyjamas to work because they were out of clean clothes.
Salvadore was drinking on their lunch hour and came back to work inebriated.
Hubert was drinking on their lunch hour while entertaining clients and came back to work inebriated.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
You selected the CORRECT answers.

The answers are:

  • Mandy intentionally broke their Manager’s chair in anger.
  • Nancy wore their pyjamas to work because she was out of clean clothes.
  • Salvadore was drinking on their lunch hour and came back to work inebriated.
  • Hubert was drinking on their lunch hour while entertaining clients and came back to work inebriated.

Mandy, Nancy, Salvadore and Hubert were all personally responsible for their actions.

Christian was not personally responsible for the chair breaking; it was an accident.

Everton was not personally responsible for their actions since they were acting on information from their Manager.

_incorrect.final:
Unfortunately, you selected the INCORRECT answers.

The correct answers are:

  • Mandy intentionally broke their Manager’s chair in anger.
  • Nancy wore their pyjamas to work because they was out of clean clothes.
  • Salvadore was drinking on their lunch hour and came back to work inebriated.
  • Hubert was drinking on their lunch hour while entertaining clients and came back to work inebriated.

Mandy, Nancy, Salvadore and Hubert were all personally responsible for their actions.

Christian was not personally responsible for the chair breaking; it was an accident.

Everton was not personally responsible for their actions since they were acting on information from his Manager.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Your answer is only PARTLY CORRECT.

The correct answers are:

  • Mandy intentionally broke their Manager’s chair in anger.
  • Nancy wore their pyjamas to work because she was out of clean clothes.
  • Salvadore was drinking on their lunch hour and came back to work inebriated.
  • Hubert was drinking on their lunch hour while entertaining clients and came back to work inebriated.

Mandy, Nancy, Salvadore and Hubert were all personally responsible for their actions.

Christian was not personally responsible for the chair breaking; it was an accident.

Everton was not personally responsible for their actions since they were acting on information from their Manager.

title: Is the offence considered Misconduct?
body:
To determine whether the offence amounts to misconduct within the meaning of the Act, we must look at the various reasons given for dismissal.

The reasons for an offence to be considered misconduct have been broken down into seven main categories.

  • 7.3.1 Absence From Work
  • 7.3.2 Insubordination
  • 7.3.3 Hostile Behaviour
  • 7.3.4 Breach of Rules
  • 7.3.5 Incarceration
  • 7.3.6 Loss of Driver’s Licence
  • 7.3.7 Unlawful Union Activity

Select the link to learn more about the seven main categories of misconduct: Digest of Benefit Entitlement Principles Chapter 7.3

We will examine each of these categories in turn.

title: Unlawful Union Activities
body:
An employee has the right to be a member of the union of choice and to participate in its lawful activities. Lawful activities are those that are allowed under the various provincial or federal laws dealing with labour relations or an agreement between employer and union within the framework of a collective agreement or some sort of labour contract.

The loss of employment resulting from exercising this right is not misconduct.

Which of these two examples would be considered an unlawful activity?
instruction: Choose one answer and then select Submit to complete this question and continue.

_items.text: The formation of a union where recruitment is done outside of working hours.
Holding meetings or soliciting members during working hours without the employer's consent.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
The answer is Holding meetings or soliciting members during working hours without the employer's consent.

This is an unlawful activity. The formation of a union would be an unlawful activity if recruitment was done within working hours.

_incorrect.final:
The correct answer is Holding meetings or soliciting members during working hours without the employer's consent.

This is an unlawful activity. The formation of a union would be an unlawful activity if recruitment was done within working hours.

title: Breach of Rules
body:
A breach of rules means that the employee has broken their promise to follow the rules as laid out by the employer.

There are several rules, when broken, which would result in misconduct.
instruction: Select each title to learn more about how someone might breach the rules of their employment. Open/read all five accordions to complete this section and continue.

_items.title: Dress and Appearance
_items.body:
Failure to report to work dressed in the authorized manner, such as wearing a uniform or wearing the uniform after hours when prohibited can amount to misconduct.

Misconduct is proven when the employee fails to respect requirements concerning the length of hair or beard when it is a question of hygiene, safety or company image.

_items.title: Safety Rules
_items.body: It is misconduct when the breach of safety rules is deliberate or occurred after a warning, or when errors are due to negligence or inattentiveness.

_items.title: Impairment and Addictions
_items.body:
Situations may occur where the claimant and/or the employer will indicate that the incident that resulted in dismissal was brought about by the claimant’s problem with, or addiction to alcohol, drugs or gambling. While such addiction is recognized as an illness, jurisprudence has held that it does not exempt the claimant from their obligations with regard to their employment, nor does it excuse the actions which violated the contract of employment.

Ultimately, only expert evidence which clearly and unequivocally establishes that the claimant themselves could not form any intent may be accepted as an excuse. This evidence would have to be very strong and show that the problem/addiction (i.e. alcohol) prevented the claimant from having any wilful thought. This evidence will probably only occur in rare instances.

The employer may have no alternative but to dismiss the employee. If the claimant lost their job because they failed to show up for work as a result of an addiction, there is no doubt that they lost the job due to their own misconduct.

_items.title: Dereliction of Duty
_items.body:
Is defined as:

• acts or omissions that are incompatible with the objectives of an employment contract;

• that present a conflict of interest with the employer’s activities; and

• have a negative effect on the relationship of trust between the parties.

It also includes cases when there is a violation of a law, a regulation, or of a professional code of ethics that results in the employee no longer meeting the conditions of employment.

_items.title: Misuse of Company Resources
_items.body: Misuse of company resources can have many different forms. It may be by making unauthorized long distance telephone calls, using company equipment for personal use or submitting inaccurate expense accounts. Taking gifts from customers or suppliers in return for using their services or purchasing their equipment or products is also a misuse of company resources.

_items.title: Criminal Charges and Offences
_items.body: An offence that constitutes an infraction or a criminal act, which results in a conviction under the Criminal Code that leads to dismissal because the employee can no longer meet the conditions of employment, would be considered misconduct.

title: Question 1
body: Which rule is being breached?
instruction: Match the situation to the rule by using the drop-down menu. Once you are done, select Submit to check your answer and complete this question.

_items.text: Samantha, an advertising executive, is convicted of shoplifting

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: The answer is: Criminal offence

_incorrect.final: The correct answer is: Criminal offence

title: Scenario 1
body:
Teresita Tormé was caught drinking on the job in March. At that time, her employer sent her home and gave her a warning that she would be dismissed if it happened again. Teresita’s work performance hasn’t been 100% since she was given the warning but it has met the basics of the job requirements, barely. In November, Teresita’s employer fires her for misconduct.

Can the reason for Teresita’s dismissal in fact be deemed as misconduct?

The answer to all four questions must be Yes. title: Scenario 2
body:
Michael Ritter was a model employee until he started to arrive late to work on an almost daily basis. Michael did not provide any explanation for his tardiness. His employer gave him some leeway for the first month since he was one of their best employees, despite his being late; however, when the tardiness continued into the next month, his employer warned him that if the behaviour continued, he would be fired the next time it happened. The day after receiving the warning, Michael was late yet again and his employer let him go for misconduct..

Can the reason for Michael’s dismissal in fact be deemed as misconduct?
instruction: Choose an answer then select Submit to complete this question.

_items.text: Yes. The reason for dismissal can be deemed as misconduct.
No. The reason for dismissal cannot be deemed as misconduct.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
The answer is: Yes. The reason for dismissal can be deemed as misconduct.

In answer to the first question, the immediate cause for Michael’s dismissal was the alleged offense.

In answer to the second question, Michael did in fact commit the offence.

In answer to the third question, the offence committed by Michael is considered misconduct. Tardiness is considered absence from work and, as per the contract of employment, an employee must report to work at the agreed starting time.

In answer to the fourth question, Michael was aware that he could be fired for his behaviour but he showed a wilful nature by arriving late after receiving the warning.

_incorrect.final:
The correct answer is: Yes. The reason for dismissal can be deemed as misconduct.

In answer to the first question, the immediate cause for Michael’s dismissal was the alleged offense.

In answer to the second question, Michael did in fact commit the offence.

In answer to the third question, the offence committed by Michael is considered misconduct. Tardiness is considered absence from work and, as per the contract of employment, an employee must report to work at the agreed starting time.

In answer to the fourth question, Michael was aware that he could be fired for his behaviour but he showed a wilful nature by arriving late after receiving the warning.

title: Scenario  3
body:
There is zero tolerance for unauthorized absences at ABC Grocer’s where Boni Mathers works. Boni asked her shift manager if she could take a day off later that month to take her son to a medical appointment. The shift supervisor said yes but did not not log Boni’s scheduled absence into the system. When Boni returned to work the day after the medical appointment, her manager fired her for misconduct saying she was absent without permission. The shift supervisor who had verbally approved the leave had quit the week before so was not there to confirm that Boni had asked for and been granted permission to take the day off.

Can the reason for Boni’s dismissal in fact be deemed as misconduct?
instruction: Choose an answer then select Submit to complete this question.

_items.text: Yes. The reason for dismissal can be deemed as Misconduct.
No. The reason for dismissal cannot be deemed as Misconduct.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
The answer is: No. The reason for dismissal cannot be deemed as misconduct.

Although the answer to both the first and second question is Yes (the absence was the immediate cause for dismissal and Boni did in fact commit the alleged offence), the answer to question three is No. Although Boni’s absence was not recorded in the system and the shift supervisor was not there to confirm that permission had been given, Boni had in fact asked for and been granted permission to take the day off. Therefore, the reason for dismissal cannot be deemed as misconduct.

In this instance, you would not need to answer the fourth question.

_incorrect.final:
The correct answer is: No. The reason for dismissal cannot be deemed as misconduct.

Although the answer to both the first and second question is Yes (the absence was the immediate cause for dismissal and Boni did in fact commit the alleged offence), the answer to question three is No. Although Boni’s absence was not recorded in the system and the shift supervisor was not there to confirm that permission had been given, Boni had in fact asked for and been granted permission to take the day off. Therefore, the reason for dismissal cannot be deemed as misconduct.

title: Summary – Misconduct
body:
You have now learned how to: 

  • explain Misconduct for Integrity purposes; and
  • apply the four questions in order to determine if the termination of employment can be deemed as misconduct.

Misconduct, for our purposes, is considered as improper behaviour or conduct.

Misconduct does not have to occur at the workplace or during work hours, as long as the offence led to the dismissal.

The four questions that must be answered to prove misconduct are:

  • Was the alleged offence the immediate cause for dismissal?
  • Does the information in this case suggest that the claimant did in fact commit the offence?
  • Is the offence considered misconduct?
  • Was the offence committed because of ill-intentioned voluntary or wilful actions performed by the claimant?

If the answers to the four questions are affirmative, then misconduct has been proven.

title: Knowledge Check - Misconduct Definition
body: How would you explain misconduct for Integrity purposes?
instruction: Enter your answer then select Submit complete this question. Note you are limited to 500 characters.
modelAnswer:
Did you get it right?

Misconduct is improper behavior that constitutes ill-intentioned voluntary or willful actions by an employee for which they were personally responsible and that are incompatible with the reliable and suitable carrying out of the duties for which the employee was hired. These actions do not have to occur at work or occur outside of working hours to be considered Misconduct as long as they led to the dismissal.   Certain actions will not be considered as Misconduct, such as incompetence, unless proven that it is a result of the willful actions or unwillingness on the part of the claimant.

title: Rights and Obligations
body:
A contract of employment creates rights and obligations on both parties, one obligation being that the employee report for work on the given date and at the agreed starting time.

When they cannot do so, employees should take all the steps available to protect their employment such as informing the employer in advance or as soon as possible, about the absence and being late, explaining the reasons and requesting permission, especially if the absence or lateness is not due to imminent circumstances. Arriving continually late for work or taking extended breaks or mealtime constitutes Misconduct.
instruction: Select each title to learn more about a contract of employment and the steps an employee must take to protect themselves. Open/read all four accordions to complete this section and continue.

_items.title: Contract of Employment
_items.body:
There are two types of employment contracts:

Contract “OF” Service

In a Contract “OF” Service, the worker is Obligated to the Employer = employee-employer relationship.

Example: Samantha signs a six-month contract with a producing electronic devices enterprise on the assembly line.

Contract “FOR” Service

In a Contract “FOR” Service, the worker is free of an employer-employee relationship, they are considered self-employed.

Example: Mark signed a contract to design and build a website for Sally’s Sassy Shoes Emporium and deliver it in two-months.

_items.title: Employee’s Responsibility
_items.body: When employees want time off, for whatever reason, it is their responsibility to notify the employer as soon as possible to seek approval. If this is not possible due to an unexpected or compelling absence, the employee is required to notify the employer before leaving or as soon as possible if unable to report to work.

_items.title: Reason for Absence
_items.body: An employer is entitled to know the reason an employee is absent from work. A refusal or failure to provide an explanation or making oneself absent for vague or non-pressing reasons, would lead to a finding of Misconduct (especially if repeated).

_items.title: Permission to be Absent
_items.body:
When permission to be absent has not been granted by the employer, the claimant must prove the absence was necessary and unavoidable.

When permission to be absent has been requested by the claimant and denied by the employer, a determination is required of what the actual circumstances were and if other reasonable alternatives existed.

title: Hostile Behaviour and Misconduct
body: Take a moment to think about what constitutes misconduct in regards to hostile behaviour.
instruction: Once you have thought about it, select the image of the hostile person to see the information on this subject.

_items.title: What constitutes misconduct in regards to hostile behaviour?
_items.body:
Acts of hostility as reflected in language, harassment or attitude, particularly following a warning, normally constitutes misconduct.

However, consideration should be given to whether or not profanity or obscene language is common on the job. An example of this could be the use of profanity at a logging camp may be very common. Conversely, the use of abusive language in a retail outlet, especially in front of customers, is not common or acceptable.

Sexual or other types of harassment are considered unacceptable behaviour and would be deemed as misconduct. In such cases, care must be taken when the fact-finding is carried out.

Intentional or deliberate destruction of company property constitutes misconduct.

When an act of violence has been committed in a place other than work, cause and effect must be assessed.

Misconduct should be concluded when the infraction results in no longer meeting the condition for employment and has led to the dismissal.

_graphic.alt: What constitutes misconduct in regards to hostile behaviour?

title: Hostile Behaviour
body:
• Disrespectful conduct (this includes acts of sexual or other harassment); and
  • Acts of violence.

An employee, who continually disrupts the harmony of the work operation, whether it be with supervisors or co-workers, may be found to have lost the employment due to misconduct.

title: Was the offence committed because of ill-intentioned voluntary or willful actions performed by the claimant?
displayTitle: Was the offence committed because of ill-intentioned voluntary or willful actions performed by the claimant?
body:
This additional question arises from judgments on appeals of previous decisions.

Wilful nature:

Did the claimant know they could be fired at the time they committed the act(s)?

This has a significant impact on the decision that will be rendered.

An exhaustive collection of facts on this subject must be made before submitting the file for decision.

Wilfulness exists when the employee acted (or failed to act) deliberately. Wilfulness also exists when the action was so negligent or careless that it appears deliberate.

Wilfulness means that the evidence reasonably leads to the conclusion the claimant knew the conduct was prohibited or neglectful, but chose to continue the course of conduct anyway. 

(Digest of Benefit Entitlement Principles 7.2.4.4.)

body:
The ROE states dismissed. The application for benefits states unjustly fired due to being absent.

Resolution:

Documentation shows contact was made with Jacques Reid, Human Resource Manager, who provided the following information about the claimant’s attendance and tardiness at work.

_items.body:
June 1: Late 15 minutes. Verbal warning.

June 18: Late 20 minutes. Verbal warning given.

June 24: Absent, did not advise employer of illness until next day. Written warning.

_items.title: July
_items.body:

_items.title: Evidence of Misconduct
_items.body: As you can see from the information provided by Jacques Reid, there is evidence of misconduct. However, after this information is obtained, the claimant must be given the opportunity to comment on the employer’s statement before a recommendation is made.

title: Information from Employers and Claimants
body:
Demanding Information from Employers

While Subsection 126(14) of the EI Act allows us to demand information from persons in order to complete our recommendation, this is generally not used to compel employers to release information to us.

Demanding Information from Claimants

 Subsection 50(5)  of the EI Act requires a claimant to comply with our requests when it relates to their claim for benefits. We will use this aspect of the legislation to compel claimants to answer questions and/or provide supporting documentation.

In the event that we have evidence from the employer that states the claimant was dismissed due to Misconduct and the claimant refuses to rebut those claims, an indefinite disqualification D-10 (Dismissal – Misconduct) is recommended.

If the claimant and employer both refuse to supply information, recommend a D-15 disentitlement for refusing to supply information.
instruction: Select each title to learn more about Subsections 126(14) and 50(5). Open both accordions to complete this activity.

_items.title: Subsection 126 (14) - Requirement to provide documents and information
_items.body:
(14) Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, but subject to subsection (15), the Commission may for any purpose relating to the administration or enforcement of this Act, other  than Part IV, by notice served personally or by confirmed delivery service, require that any person provide, within such reasonable time as stated in the notice, 

(a) any information or additional information, including any information return or supplementary return; or

(b) any document.

_items.title: Subsection 50 (5) - Additional information
_items.body: (5) The Commission may at any time, require a claimant to provide additional information about their claim for benefits.

title: Question 1
body:
Jill was hired two weeks ago as a gas station attendant. She worked with two other employees. They all shared the same cash register. On Thursday, the till was $20 short. The manager immediately fired Jill as she was the new employee and they never had a cash shortage before.

Jill denied that she took the money.

What recommendation would you make in this case?

title: Question 2
body:
Xavier has been a mechanic for over 20 years and has worked with ‘You Wreck It, We Fix It’ Auto Body Shop for the last five years. Xavier had always been a friendly person but started to exhibit mildly aggressive behaviour towards the clients over the past several months. None of the customers complained, thinking he was just having a bad day. However, after the shop owner observed several of these incidents, Xavier was fired for misconduct.

Xavier did not deny that he had been aggressive.

What recommendation would you make in this case?

title: Benefit  of the Doubt
body:
Although the following issues were illustrated within the Voluntary Leaving (VL) module, they equally apply to misconduct:

  • Rebuttal;
  • Credibility;
  • Mandatory Fact-Finding; and
  • Benefit of the Doubt.

Similar to VL, fact-finding starts with Who, What, Where, When, Why and How. The majority of reasons for which a person is fired are grouped together within ten categories.

Generally, a person is not fired for being absent. They are fired for not advising their employer of the absence.

It is unacceptable to conclude that the claimant was fired due to absenteeism or lateness. The details of the incidents and the employer actions must be documented. Documentation of the incidents, warnings and consequences of the actions are required.

In some cases, the accounts given by the parties may all seem equally credible, making it impossible to choose one version over another. When faced with equally credible versions of the facts, the benefit of the doubt will be given to the claimant.

The benefit of the doubt is not given merely because there are contradictory versions of the facts present. 

The expression “to give benefit of the doubt” to someone simply means that when both sides of the story have equal balance and weight, credibility is given to the claimant.

title: Dictionary and Working Definitions
body:
Black’s Law Dictionary Definition

Misconduct is a wilful or wanton disregard of the employer’s interest, carelessness or negligence of such degree to manifest wrongful intent or evil design.

Merriam-Webster Dictionary Definition

Webster’s dictionary uses a simpler term in defining misconduct as:

  • Improper Behaviour

Our Working Definition

For our definition of misconduct, we will simplify the Black’s Law definition to:

  • Wilful, wanton disregard of the employer’s interest; and
  • Negligence or carelessness that equates to wrongful intent or evil design.

Therefore, for our purposes, misconduct can be considered “improper behaviour” or “improper conduct.”

title: Example Using Black’s Law Definition
body:
In the Federal Court case v. Tucker (FCA A-381-85), the Court stated that misconduct was not defined in the legislation; therefore, the Court adopted the definition from Black’s Law Dictionary:

In the Tucker case, the Court assessed a case of misconduct in which an airline attendant took prescription drugs from a co-worker, which caused her to become incapacitated. The Court ruled no misconduct took place, as there was no wilful or wanton wrongful intent or evil design. She took the drugs expecting to get better but they provided an adverse effect.

Select the link to learn more. The full text of the court’s decision in case FC A-381-85 can be found in the Jurisprudence Library.

title: Insubordination
body:
•  Refusal to perform certain duties;
  •  Refusal to carry out order(s) or instruction(s); and
  •  Refusal to work overtime.

The refusal to carry out a legitimate order, which is reasonable and not in violation of a collective agreement, constitutes Misconduct.

title: Reason for Dismissal
body:
It is the responsibility of the employer to show that the claimant was blameworthy of unlawful activities.

It is important, when investigating cases of this nature, that the real reason for the dismissal be established. This involves complete fact-finding from both the employee and the employer.

When an employee is dismissed for reason of union activities during a labour dispute, the first question to resolve is which provision of the legislation is relevant: the one pertaining to labour disputes, or the one pertaining to Misconduct.

title: Summary – Fact-finding
body:
You have now learned:

  • How to explain the fact-finding process as it applies to dismissal for misconduct;
  • The onus of proof to establish misconduct rests with the Commission;
  • Fact-finding should start with the employer so that the claimant can be given the last say on the issue;
  • The benefit of the doubt is given to the claimant when it cannot be determined from the facts which version of events is the reality of what happened;
  • When the employer refuses to provide information we generally do not use the EI Act to compel them to do so;
  • When the claimant refuses to provide information, we can use the EI Act to compel them to comply;
  • If the claimant refuses to rebut evidence from the employer stating the claimant was dismissed due to misconduct, a D-10 disqualification is recommended; and
  • In some situations, such as with health issues or a change to the ROE, misconduct is no longer an issue.
